newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Budapest bourse ends easier, seen flat short-term.
newsitem.headline: Budapest bourse ends easier, seen flat short-term.

text.p: Hungarian share prices closed mixed on Friday, pulling the BUX index lower as the market's downward correction entered its second day, traders said.
The BUX index finished at a preliminary 7,162.40 points, down 56.80 points or 0.79 percent.

Traders said the market's recent rally, which bolstered the BUX index by eight percent, justified the downward correction but gave no reason to believe the market's long-term upward trend would change.
But they added they expected a virtually stagnant market in the short-term.

"I think today's fall fully fits in with expectations," said Geza Raner of Bank Austria-Investment Rt. "It's just a cautious decline, there might be a 0.5 percent dip (on Monday) then the market will become flat."
Another trader also believed the market would turn calmer for a while but he attributed this to summer holidays.

"Foreign investors are starting their holidays and I think smaller funds are closing their positions," the trader said. "However, I think, they are doing so mainly in London (on SEAQ) and price falls on SEAQ leave their impact in Budapest."
Frances Cloud, analyst at Nomura Equity Research in London said, the upcoming earnings reporting period might raise slight concerns, but will eventually leave the market little changed.

"There's some very, very gentle profit-taking, and maybe a bit of slightly increasing caution ahead of reporting of the first half figures," Cloud said. "The market will do very little until we see the results."
Bourse listed companies have to submit their first half earnings reports to the exchange by August 15.
On Friday chemicals TVK finished at 3,665 forints, down 35; oil and gas firm MOL at 4,250 forints, down 25; pharmaceuticals Richter remained steady at 17,150.
